OPLANNING THE TEST
WRITING MULTIPLE CHOICE
TEST ITEMS
DEFINE THE GOALS...
The initial step in planning a test is to carefully identify your goals. Think of your test as a well-planned sampling

of the concepts you expect students to learn in the course. The test scores have meaning only to the extent that

should not consist entirely of questions which only require regurgitating isolated facts. Instead, the questions

The following guidelines for constructing multiple choice items are only a very brief summary. The references
signs and symptoms indicates hypertension
listed at the end of this paper are useful sources of information about writing and critiquing test items related
to health science education.
Table 1
1. The item stem should have meaning by itself and should concisely present a complete problem.
2. Include as much of the item as possible in the stem.
Avoid negatively worded stems unless the negative aspect is critical to the problem situation.
Table of Specifications for a
4. Extraneous material in the item should be avoided.
Dental Treatment Planning Test
5. The correct answer should clearly be the best alternative.
6. Each of the distractors should be plausible to a naive student.
7. Cues which lead to the correct answer or away from distractors should be carefully avoided.
Factual
Simple
Problen
8. "All of the above" should not be used in a one-best response item.
Recall
Interpretation
Solving
Total
Content Areas
Items
The final step in test item writing is to try out the items on at least one colleague BEFORE using them with
students. If he/she is unsure of any correct answer, discuss the ambiguity, and then redesign the item.
